name: Amateur hour
description: Early sound equipment allowed filmmakers and amateurs alike the ability to experiment often with affordable 16mm film.

key_work.title: Early sound recording equipment
key_work.brief_description: In 1935, the world’s first sound-on-film camera was released for the amateur market, the RCA Victor Sound 16mm camera. Like RCA’s Photophone system, it recorded sound directly onto the film’s edge via light reflected off a mirror, which was attached to a diaphragm that vibrated when the operator spoke.

start.title: PR-25 16mm Sound Cinecamera
start.brief_description: The RCA Victor Sound 16mm Camera was introduced in 1934, five years after Hollywood’s conversion to sound pictures. It was the world’s first 16mm sound on film camera and an early technical leap in the sound-on-film process for the amateur market.

end.title: Early Amateur Sound Film (1936–37)
end.brief_description: Amateur filmmaker Archie Stewart used an RCA Sound Camera to document family life from 1935. A member of the Amateur Cinema League, in 1937 he published one of the first articles on amateur sound, ‘A Talkie Movie Maker Speaks’, in the league’s magazine.

links.description: You wouldn’t consider him an amateur now, but director Christopher Nolan never studied film. His debut Following, was produced with almost amateur production values. Shot on black-and-white 16mm film that intensified the grittiness, scenes were heavily rehearsed to reduce takes.

links.description: Kelly Reichardt also used 16mm to shoot Certain Women. Originally intending to shoot the film digitally, Reichardt and her DP Chris Blauvelt decided to use 16mm for Certain Women to capitalise on its warm grain and texture.
